11. 
whether "the original entries were magnetic or true"?. 
Since Dr Shaw has cast this unwarranted doubt 
it is necessary to trace the result in the body of the 
volume. 
On page 489 Mr R.H.Curtis goes a step further 
and assume that the wind directions are 'magnetic', 
lightly veiling the assumption with an "if". 
Following this on page 490 appears a tabulated 
summary of the winds observed on various <s>j<\s>journeys and at 
the bottom of this page a 'mean correlation for variation' 
is applied which secures a preponderance of Easterly winds 
on Lieut. Royds' journey. 
It would appear that a single glance at the 
summaries of other journeys on this page and the excess 
of Southerly and South Westerly winds recorded would have 
shown the mistake of applying this 'correction'. 
But what of the feelings of Lieutenant Royds 
and Mr Bernacchi? These officers with a keen recollection 
of their arduous journey are confronted with a table which 
reverses the winds they experienced and noted. It is no 
flight of fancy to assert that this table suggests that 
frost bites they remember on the right cheek were really 
on the left and Vice Versa. 
In point of fact a statement is arrived at 
which<s>,<\s> is ridiculous to members of the Expedition and 
gravely misleading to Scientific Investigators. 
I return to the second crucial test which Dr 
Shaw (page X11) states to have failed "through very slight 
<u>omissions<\u>
